Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Negotiated Resource Sharing Strategies to Facilitate New Product Introductions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The introduction of new products is an important basis for competition in many industries. Effective management of new product introductions requires collaboration and coordination between different units such as sales and marketing, manufacturing, and product engineering. Each unit controls some critical resources and information, but depends on resources and information from other units to perform its function. The resulting competition for manufacturing capacity between units with different objectives, often arbitrated by a central decision maker, may result in delayed, suboptimal decisions. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project studies the opportunity for new, decentralized approaches that encourage information sharing among functional units to provide better alternatives to centralized control. The project will yield new insights into multiparty negotiation as well as contributing to the national welfare through insights into how to better manage new product introduction in industrial, non-profit and defence environments. The award will provide support for a graduate student working with the PI.

This project will evaluate the merits of two novel approaches to structuring decentralized decision making. The first will involve the emerging field of algorithmic game theory to develop computationally efficient approximation algorithms for determining equilibrium solutions for these problems. The second will involve the study of combinatorial auctions, where each unit bids for manufacturing capacity across different time periods. The extensive literature on game theory and combinatorial auctions present an opportunity to develop novel formulations of this problem. Several streams of research address different aspects of the problem, but none is currently capable of modelling even simplified versions of the problem in all aspects. Hence at the current stage of knowledge it is not clear what direction a concerted attack on this problem with these tools should take. The objective of this EAGER project is to clarify this issue, identifying the most promising lines of attack while eliminating those unlikely to succeed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal objective of this project was to explore the potential for decentralized approaches to coordinate manufacturing and product development activities during product transitions, the phase-out of an older product and its replacement with a new, enhanced product in the market. The firm?s manufacturing organization (MFG) must produce current products that maintain the firm's revenue stream and market presence while also providing capacity to multiple Product Development (PDG) units for prototype development and debugging. Since domain knowledge of manufacturing and product development is located within the respective functional units, this requires a decentralized solution approach; monolithic, integrated models that consider the same level of detail within each unit are impossible to solve and to maintain. Many functional units have already developed decision support tools for their local problems; these can be harnessed by a decentralized decision architecture that converges rapidly to mutually consistent (i.e.) implementable) solutions for all units while ensuring corporate-level objectives are not unduly degraded by emphasis on local performance measures by the units.

Our first step in this project was to create a simplified environment to serve s a basis for further study. We represent each PDG as facing a multiple resource constrained multiple project scheduling problem, and the MFG unit a capacity-constrained production planning problem. MFG cannot initiate production of a product until all development activities have been completed by the appropriate PDG. An integrated, monolithic formulation was developed to determine resource allocations by MFG to current products and PDGs, and internal resource allocation decisions by the PDGs, to maximize the firm?s total profit over a finite planning horizon. This serves two purposes: it provides a benchmark for our computational experiments with decentralized methods, and a theoretical point of departure for alternative decomposition methods that lead to decentralized approaches.

Given the interdependency of decisions across time for the individual units and across units for the firm, we approach the problem using combinatorial auctions where the PDGs bid for a portfolio of MFG capacity allocations in different periods, while MFG seeks to have products ready for introduction in order to meet demand and maximize profit. MFG serves as the auctioneer, communicating prices for capacity in each period to the different PDGs are receiving bids in the form of capacity requests. A Lagrangian decomposition allows us to use the subgradient algorithm to emulate the price tatonnement that yields an approximately optimal solution to the integrated problem. The resulting auction procedure is capable of price discrimination, charging different PDGs different prices for capacity in a given period based on the desirability of the products each PDG is developing. Subsequent work has led to the development of a column generation approach to emulating the combinatorial auction, which has resulted in solutions with much smaller duality gaps and reduced computation times by an order of magnitude.

An important question in this problem is that of ensuring truthful behavior by the PDGs. This requires that the PDGs accurately represent their capabilities to the auctioneer, as opposed to providing only solutions that are advantageous to that particular PDG but have adverse impacts on the performance of other PDGs and, perhaps, MFG. This requires that each PDG submit, in addition to the solution that optimizes its local objective function, a set of solutions (bids) that give the auctioneer the flexibility to impose locally suboptimal performance on some PDGs to improve the firm?s total profit. We show that this approach is incentive compatible as long as the cost to a PDG of receiving no capacity allocation is high, a condition that is easily satisfied in practice due to the high fixed costs of PDGs and their lack of direct external revenue streams.

The combinatorial auction approach followed requires the solution of multiple integer programs at each iteration of the procedure. To enhance the computational efficiency of this procedure we have also developed a novel primal heuristic for binary integer programs that yields excellent results on a variety of hard test instances.

The work in this project is, to the best of our knowledge, the first to use mathematical programming models to formulate combinatorial auctions for this complex resource allocation problem, taking into account the complex operational constraints under which MFG and the PDGs must operate. The project has supported one PhD student at NC State, and catalyzed the formation of an interdisciplinary research team from industry and academia that has successfully developed a more extensive project to address this important problem.
